entry.title: KWUR 90.3 FM St. Louis Underground Radio
Tell Me Something I Don’t Know (Rebroadcast)
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: The debut of a live game show from Freakonomics Radio, with judges Malcolm Gladwell, Ana Gasteyer, and David Paterson.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: “If Mayors Ruled the World”
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Unlike certain elected officials in Washington, mayors all over the country actually get stuff done. So maybe we should ask them to do more?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Why Does Everyone Hate Flying? And Other Questions Only a Pilot Can Answer
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Patrick Smith, the author of Cockpit Confidential, answers every question we can throw at him about what really happens up in the air. Just don't get him started on pilotless planes -- or whether the autopilot is actually doing the flying.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Think Like a Child (Rebroadcast)
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: When it comes to generating ideas and asking questions it can be really fruitful to have the mentality of an eight year old.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: How Much Does a Good Boss Really Matter?
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: It's harder than you'd think to measure the value of a boss. But some enterprising economists have done just that -- and the news is good.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Is There a Better Way to Fight Terrorism?
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: The White House is hosting an anti-terror summit next week. Summits being what they are, we try to offer some useful advice.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Parking Is Hell
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: There ain't no such thing as a free parking spot. Somebody has to pay for it -- and that somebody is everybody.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Fixing the World, Bang-for-the-Buck Edition
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: A team of economists has been running the numbers on the U.N.'s development goals. They have a different view of how those billions of dollars should be spent.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: How to Make a Smart TV Ad
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Step 1: Hire a Harvard psych professor as the pitchman. Step 2: Have him help write the script ...
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: The Economics of Sleep, Part 1
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Could a lack of sleep help explain why some people get much sicker than others?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Why You Should Bribe Your Kids
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Educational messaging looks good on paper but kids don’t respond to it -- and adults aren’t much better.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: How American Food Got So Bad
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Tyler Cowen points fingers. There's plenty of blame to go around.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: The House of Dreams
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Dubner's childhood home goes from sacred to profane -- and then back again.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: The Troubled Cremation of Stevie the Cat
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: We spend billions on our pets, and one of the fastest-growing costs is pet "aftercare." But are those cremated remains you got back really from your pet?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: How Much Does the President Really Matter? (Rebroadcast)
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: The U.S. president is often called the "leader of free world." But if you ask an economist or a Constitutional scholar how much the occupant of the Oval Office matters, they won't say much. We look at what the data have to say about measuring leadership, and its impact on the economy and the country.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Make Me a Match
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Sure, markets generally work well. But for some transactions -- like school admissions and organ transplants -- money alone can't solve the problem. That's when you need a market-design wizard like Al Roth.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Why Online Poker Should Be Legal
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: The data show that poker is indeed a game of skill, not chance, and a Federal judge agrees. So why are players still being treated like criminals?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: What Are You Waiting For?
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Standing in line represents a particularly sloppy - and frustrating - way for supply and demand to meet. Why haven't we found a better way to get what we want? Is it possible that we secretly enjoy waiting in line? And might it even be (gulp) good for us?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Why Everybody Who Doesn’t Hate Bitcoin Loves It
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Thinking of Bitcoin as just a digital currency is like thinking about the Internet as just e-mail. Its potential is much more exciting than that.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Who Needs Handwriting?
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: The digital age is making pen and paper seem obsolete. But what are we giving up if we give up on handwriting?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Think Like a Child
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: When it comes to generating ideas and asking questions it can be really fruitful to have the mentality of an eight year old.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: REBROADCAST: The Upside of Quitting
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: You know the saying: a winner never quits and a quitter never wins. To which Freakonomics Radio says ... Are you sure?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Is America’s Education Problem Really Just a Teacher Problem?
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: If U.S. schoolteachers are indeed “just a little bit below average,” it’s not really their fault. So what should be done about it?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Introducing “Freakonomics Experiments”
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Steve Levitt has a novel idea for helping people make tough decisions
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Which Came First, the Chicken or the Avocado?
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: When it comes to exercising outrage, people tend to be very selective. Could it be that humans are our least favorite animal?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: How to Be Less Terrible at Predicting the Future
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Experts and pundits are notoriously bad at forecasting, in part because they aren't punished for bad predictions. Also, they tend to be deeply unscientific. The psychologist Philip Tetlock is finally turning prediction into a science -- and now even you could become a superforecaster.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: The Longest Long Shot
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: When the uncelebrated Leicester City Football Club won the English Premier League, it wasn't just the biggest underdog story in recent history. It was a sign of changing economics -- and that other impossible, wonderful events might be lurking just around the corner.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Does This Recession Make Me Look Fat?
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: A look at some non-obvious ways to lose weight.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Do Baby Girls Cause Divorce?
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Even American parents have a strong "son preference" -- which means that a newborn daughter can be bad news for a marriage.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Who Owns the Words That Come Out of Your Mouth?
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: The very long reach of Winston Churchill -- and how the British government is remaking copyright law.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: How Many Doctors Does It Take to Start a Healthcare Revolution?
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: The practice of medicine has been subsumed by the business of medicine. This is great news for healthcare shareholders -- and bad news for pretty much everyone else.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Preventing Crime for Pennies on the Dollar
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Conventional programs tend to be expensive, onerous, and ineffective. Could something as simple (and cheap) as cognitive behavioral therapy do the trick?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: The Things They Taught Me
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: College, at its best, is about learning to think. Stephen Dubner chats up three of his former professors who made the magic happen.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Is the Internet Being Ruined?
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: It's a remarkable ecosystem that allows each of us to exercise control over our lives. But how much control do we truly have? How many of our decisions are really being made by Google and Facebook and Apple? And, perhaps most importantly: is the Internet's true potential being squandered?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Are You Ready for a Glorious Sunset?
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: We spend billions on end-of-life healthcare that doesn't do much good. So what if a patient could forego the standard treatment and get a cash rebate instead?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: REBROADCAST: Legacy of a Jerk
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: What happens to your reputation when you're no longer around to defend it?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: The Dilbert Index?
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Measuring workplace morale -- and how to game the sick-day system.

entry.title: What Do Hand-Washing and Financial Illiteracy Have in Common?
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Education is the surest solution to a lot of problems. Except when it’s not.

entry.title: Fear Thy Nature
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: What "Sleep No More" and the Stanford Prison Experiment tell us about who we really are.

entry.title: I Consult, Therefore I Am
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: There are enough management consultants these days to form a small nation. But what do they actually do? And does it work?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: You Eat What You Are, Part 1
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: How American food so got bad -- and why it's getting so much better.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: When Is a Negative a Positive?
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Sure, we all like to hear compliments. But if you're truly looking to get better at something, it's the negative feedback that will get you there.

entry.title: Food + Science = Victory!
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: A kitchen wizard and a nutrition detective talk about the perfect hamburger, getting the most out of garlic, and why you should use vodka in just about everything.

entry.title: Fitness Apartheid
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Markets are hardly perfect, but the results can be ugly when you try to subvert them.

entry.title: The Economist’s Guide to Parenting (Rebroadcast)
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Think you know how much parents matter? Think again. Economists crunch the numbers to learn the ROI on child-rearing.

entry.title: How Is a Bad Radio Station Like Our Public-School System? (Encore)
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: The thrill of customization, via Pandora and a radical new teaching method
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: The Tale of the $15 Tomato
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Trying to go rustic by baking, brewing, and knitting at home can be terribly inefficient. And that's a wonderful thing.

entry.title: That’s a Great Question!
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Verbal tic or strategic rejoinder? Whatever the case: it’s rare to come across an interview these days where at least one question isn’t a “great” one.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Do You Really Want to Know Your Future?
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: You might think that someone with a 50-50 chance of getting a fatal disease would want to know for sure -- but you would be wrong. What does this say about our supposed thirst for certainty?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Star-Spangled Banter?
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Once a week, the British Prime Minister goes before the House of Commons for a lightning round of hard questions. Should the U.S. give it a try?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Why Doesn’t Everyone Get the Flu Vaccine?
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Influenza kills, but you’d never know it by how few of us get the vaccine.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Is It Okay for Restaurants to Racially Profile Their Employees? (Rebroadcast)
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: We seem to have decided that ethnic food tastes better when it's served by people of that ethnicity (or at least something close). Does this make sense -- and is it legal?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: How to Raise Money Without Killing a Kitten (Rebroadcast)
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: The science of what works -- and doesn't work -- in fund-raising
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Ten Ideas to Make Politics Less Rotten
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: We Americans may love our democracy -- at least in theory -- but at the moment our feelings toward the federal government lie somewhere between disdain and hatred. Which electoral and political ideas should be killed off to make way for a saner system?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: How Biased Is Your Media?
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: The left and the right blame each other for pretty much everything, including slanted media coverage. Can they both be right?

entry.title: Aziz Ansari Needs Another Toothbrush
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios

entry.title: This Idea Must Die
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Every year, Edge.org asks its salon of big thinkers to answer one big question. This year's question borders on heresy: what scientific idea is ready for retirement?

entry.title: A Better Way to Eat (Rebroadcast)

entry.description: Takeru Kobayashi revolutionized the sport of competitive eating. What can the rest of us learn from his breakthrough?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: How Did the Belt Win?
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Suspenders may work better, but the dork factor is too high. How did an organ-squeezing belly tourniquet become part of our everyday wardrobe -- and what other suboptimal solutions do we routinely put up with?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Nate Silver Says: “Everyone Is Kind of Weird”
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: America's favorite statistical guru answers our FREAK-quently Asked Questions, and more.

entry.title: How to Think About Money, Choose Your Hometown, and Buy an Electric Toothbrush

entry.description: Dubner and Levitt field your queries in this latest installment of our FREAK-quently Asked Questions.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: The Suicide Paradox (Rebroadcast)
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: There are more than twice as many suicides as murders in the U.S., but suicide attracts far less scrutiny. Freakonomics Radio digs through the numbers and finds all kinds of surprises.

entry.description: Thick markets, thin markets, and the triumph of attributes over compatibility.

entry.title: The Power of the President -- and the Thumb

entry.title: Ben Bernanke Gives Himself a Grade

entry.description: He was handed the keys to the global economy just as it started heading off a cliff. Fortunately, he'd seen this movie before.

entry.description: People who sleep better earn more money. Now all we have to do is teach everyone to sleep better.

entry.title: How to Get More Grit in Your Life

entry.description: The psychologist Angela Duckworth argues that a person's level of stick-to-itiveness is directly related to their level of success. No big surprise there. But grit, she says, isn't something you're born with -- it can be learned. Here's how.

entry.title: There’s No Such Thing as a Free Appetizer

entry.title: How to Be Tim Ferriss

entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Retirement Kills
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Sure, we all dream of leaving the office forever. But what if it's bad for your health?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Help Wanted. No Smokers Need Apply
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: In many states, it is perfectly legal to not hire someone who smokes. Should employers also be able to weed out junk-food lovers or motorcyclists -- or anyone who wants to have a baby?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Should We Really Behave Like Economists Say We Do?
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: One man's attempt to remake his life in the mold of homo economicus.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: The Suicide Paradox (Rebroadcast)
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: There are more than twice as many suicides as murders in the U.S., but suicide attracts far less scrutiny. Freakonomics Radio digs through the numbers and finds all kinds of surprises.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Why America’s Economic Growth May Be (Shh!) Over
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Sure, we love our computers and all the rest of our digital toys. But when it comes to real economic gains, can we ever match old-school innovations like the automobile and electricity?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Save Me From Myself
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: A commitment device forces you to be the person you really want to be. What could possibly go wrong?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: How to Think About Guns
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: No one wants mass shootings. Unfortunately, no one has a workable plan to stop them either.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Why Are Japanese Homes Disposable?
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: In most countries, houses get more valuable over time. In Japan, a new buyer will often bulldoze the home. We'll tell you why.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Who Are the Most Successful Immigrants in the World?
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: It's impossible to say for sure, but the Lebanese do remarkably well. Why?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Lottery Loopholes and Deadly Doctors
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: What do you do when smart people keep making stupid mistakes? And: are we a nation of financial illiterates?
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: The Perils of Drunk Walking
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: We know it's terribly dangerous to drive drunk. But heading home on foot isn't the solution.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Ask Not What Your Podcast Can Do for You
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Now and again, Freakonomics Radio puts hat in hand and asks listeners to donate to the public-radio station that produces the show. Why on earth should anyone pay good money for something that can be had for free? Here are a few reasons.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Ten Years of Freakonomics
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Dubner and Levitt are live onstage at the 92nd Street Y in New York to celebrate their new book "When to Rob a Bank" -- and a decade of working together.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: What You Don’t Know About Online Dating
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description:
Thick markets, thin markets, and the triumph of attributes over compatibility.

This episode is included in the Freakonomics #smartbinge podcast playlist at wnyc.org/smartbinge
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Can You Be Too Smart for Your Own Good? And Other FREAK-quently Asked Questions
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: Dubner and Levitt talk about circadian rhythms, gay marriage, autism, and whether "pay what you want" is everything it's cracked up to be.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: What Makes a Donor Donate?

entry.description: The science of charity, with economist John List.

entry.title: “It’s Fun to Smoke Marijuana”
entry.artist: Stephen J. Dubner and WNYC Studios
entry.description: A psychology professor argues that the brain's greatest attribute is knowing what other people are thinking. And that a Queen song, played backwards, can improve your mind-reading skills.
entry.subtitle: https://itunes.apple.com/us/podcast/freakonomics-radio/id354668519?mt=2&uo=4

entry.title: Why Is “I Don’t Know” So Hard to Say?

entry.title: We the Sheeple

entry.title: Is Good Corporate Citizenship Also Good for the Bottom Line?

entry.title: NerdCast 498 - RPG Cyberpunk 3: Estrada para o inferno
entry.artist: Jovem Nerd
entry.description:
39 de dezembro de 2015, um feliz ano novo para todos, como prometido o Nerdcast Especial de RPG: Cyberpunk Parte III está sendo lançado na virada do ano, após um breve período de paralisia temporal entre 2015 e 2016 finalmente chegou o dia. E o último episódio não poderia sair em uma data mais apropriada que no aniversário de um outro conhecido replicante.
Neste podcast: Continue acompanhando as aventuras de grupo de mercenários mais sem noção de 2119. Androide, Durden, James Rexus, Oleg, Ozob e Dr. Silvana estão de volta...ou será que alguém morreu pelo caminho? ALTAMENTE RECOMENDÁVEL OUVIR COM FONES DE OUVIDO ARTE DA VITRINE: Vicente Valentine Liquidação Modafoca Nerdstore
A partir de 13/01 a 17/01 Mais detalhes no hotsite: http://www.bit.ly/liquidamodafoca
Camisetas Star Wars na Nerdstore

entry.title: NerdCast 424 - Matemática > Vida
entry.artist: Jovem Nerd
entry.description:

Neste podcast: Veja que 1+1 nem sempre é igual a 2, NUNCA divida por zero, agradeça aos seus dedos pelo sistema decimal, ouças as melhores piadas (ou não) para matemáticos e descubra o seu número de Marcos.

entry.title: NerdCast 377 - Armazenamento: Da Pedra ao Blu-ray
entry.artist: Jovem Nerd
entry.description:
Lambda lambda lambda! Hoje Alottoni, Bluehand, André Souza, Caio Gomes, Cardoso e Azaghal vão discutir a evolução das formas de guardar informações que a humanidade inventou, a história do ARMAZENAMENTO DE INFORMAÇÃO!
Neste podcast: Tudo começou na parede de uma caverna, descubra que alguém não ganha disco de platina à toa, veja que a industria adulta ajudou o VHS a dominar o mercado e remova seu pendrive com segurança depois de copiar esse Nerdcast!

entry.title: NerdCast 407 - A Aurora do Renascimento

entry.description:
Lambda lambda lambda NERDS! Hoje Alottoni, Bluehand, Eduardo Spohr, JP, Ivan Mizanzuk e Azaghal pintarão um belo quadro de tudo que rolou na RENASCENÇA!
Neste podcast: Conheça o bolsa renascença, descubra que a idade média (ou medíocre) não foi tão ruim assim, convirja para o ponto de fuga e esgote as piadas com as Tartarugas Ninja!
